citing_core_holding: The remedies under Articles 77-79 GDPR may be exercised concurrently and independently, with Member States setting procedural rules ensuring effective protection and consistent application.
citing_justification: Permits data subjects to pursue multiple remedies concurrently, maximizing avenues for enforcement of their rights.

citing_core_holding: The right of access under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR entails an obligation to provide data subjects with the actual identity of recipients to whom their data have been disclosed, unless identification is impossible or the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
citing_justification: The Court interprets the right of access broadly to require disclosure of specific recipient identities, not just categories, thereby enhancing data subject control over their personal data.

citing_core_holding: The right of access under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR entails an obligation to provide data subjects with the actual identity of recipients to whom their data have been disclosed, unless identification is impossible or the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
citing_justification: The Court interprets the right of access broadly to require disclosure of specific recipient identities, not just categories, thereby enhancing data subject control over their personal data.

citing_core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of the exception to information obligations reduces controller burdens by exempting them from providing information for controller-generated data when statutory conditions are met.

citing_core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of the exception to information obligations reduces controller burdens by exempting them from providing information for controller-generated data when statutory conditions are met.

citing_core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of the exception to information obligations reduces controller burdens by exempting them from providing information for controller-generated data when statutory conditions are met.

citing_core_holding: Supervisory authorities are competent to verify whether Member State law provides appropriate protective measures under Article 14(5)(c), but this does not extend to verifying Article 32 security measures.
citing_justification: DPA competence is affirmed for verifying protective measures (pro-data subject) but limited by excluding Article 32 security measures from the scope of review (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Supervisory authorities are competent to verify whether Member State law provides appropriate protective measures under Article 14(5)(c), but this does not extend to verifying Article 32 security measures.
citing_justification: DPA competence is affirmed for verifying protective measures (pro-data subject) but limited by excluding Article 32 security measures from the scope of review (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Processing is necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b) only if objectively indispensable for the main contractual purpose, which is not met when the contract expressly prohibits disclosure.
citing_justification: Sets high threshold for contract necessity requiring objective indispensability, protecting data subjects from disclosure contrary to contractual expectations.

citing_core_holding: Legitimate interests processing under Article 6(1)(f) requires strict necessity and a balancing test where data subject interests may override, particularly when disclosure was not reasonably expected.
citing_justification: Court emphasizes strict necessity, less intrusive alternatives, data minimisation, and reasonable expectations favoring data subject protection over third party interests.

citing_core_holding: Legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) can derive from Member State case-law provided it is clear, precise, foreseeable, meets a public interest objective, and is proportionate.
citing_justification: Court sets out conditions for legal obligation basis without definitively ruling whether German case-law meets them, leaving determination to national court.

citing_core_holding: The collection by tax authorities of a Member State from an economic operator of personal data is subject to GDPR requirements, including Article 5(1) principles.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope confirms tax authorities are subject to data protection requirements when collecting personal data.

citing_core_holding: The collection by tax authorities of a Member State from an economic operator of personal data is subject to GDPR requirements, including Article 5(1) principles.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope confirms tax authorities are subject to data protection requirements when collecting personal data.

citing_core_holding: Tax authorities may require disclosure of taxpayer data from internet service providers provided the data are necessary for specific purposes and collection period does not exceed strict necessity.
citing_justification: Permits tax authority data collection but imposes strict necessity and purpose limitation requirements protecting data subjects.

citing_core_holding: Processing personal data for prosecution serves a different purpose than collection for detection and investigation, but such subsequent processing is permitted under Directive 2016/680 Article 4(2) conditions.
citing_justification: The Court clarifies that different purposes exist but permits subsequent processing under specified conditions, neither expanding nor restricting data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR applies to processing of personal data by a public prosecutor's office when defending the State in civil damages proceedings using data originally collected for criminal purposes.
citing_justification: The Court interprets GDPR scope broadly to include processing by public authorities for civil defense purposes, ensuring data protection applies.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR applies to processing of personal data by a public prosecutor's office when defending the State in civil damages proceedings using data originally collected for criminal purposes.
citing_justification: The Court interprets GDPR scope broadly to include processing by public authorities for civil defense purposes, ensuring data protection applies.

citing_core_holding: Processing personal data by a public prosecutor's office for State defense in damages proceedings may be lawful under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as a task carried out in the public interest.
citing_justification: The Court permits public authorities to process personal data for litigation defense under the public interest basis, facilitating their defensive capabilities.

citing_core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) GDPR fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, not a punitive or deterrent one.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or restricting rights; it confirms compensation must be full but not punitive.

citing_core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) GDPR fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, not a punitive or deterrent one.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or restricting rights; it confirms compensation must be full but not punitive.

citing_core_holding: The severity and intentional nature of a GDPR infringement need not be taken into account when determining compensation under Article 82(1).
citing_justification: The holding benefits controllers by not increasing compensation for intentional violations, but also confirms presumed fault liability.

citing_core_holding: The severity and intentional nature of a GDPR infringement need not be taken into account when determining compensation under Article 82(1).
citing_justification: The holding benefits controllers by not increasing compensation for intentional violations, but also confirms presumed fault liability.

citing_core_holding: The severity and intentional nature of a GDPR infringement need not be taken into account when determining compensation under Article 82(1).
citing_justification: The holding benefits controllers by not increasing compensation for intentional violations, but also confirms presumed fault liability.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage from a data breach is not by its nature less significant than physical injury when determining compensation.
citing_justification: Elevating non-material damage to equal status with physical injury strengthens data subject compensation rights.

citing_core_holding: Courts may award minimal compensation for non-serious damage provided it fully compensates the damage actually suffered.
citing_justification: Confirms no de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but permits minimal/symbolic awards for minor damage (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Courts may award minimal compensation for non-serious damage provided it fully compensates the damage actually suffered.
citing_justification: Confirms no de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but permits minimal/symbolic awards for minor damage (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Courts may award minimal compensation for non-serious damage provided it fully compensates the damage actually suffered.
citing_justification: Confirms no de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but permits minimal/symbolic awards for minor damage (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Identity theft requires actual misuse of identity by a third party, but compensation for data theft is not limited to cases of proven identity theft.
citing_justification: Clarifies that compensation is available for data theft even without proven identity theft or fraud, lowering the burden for claimants.

citing_core_holding: Online publication of declarations of private interests is precluded where it includes name-specific data about declarant's spouse, close relatives, or transactions exceeding EUR 3000.
citing_justification: Court restricts scope of permissible online publication of personal data, requiring proportionality assessment that favors privacy over transparency.

citing_core_holding: Online publication of declarations of private interests is precluded where it includes name-specific data about declarant's spouse, close relatives, or transactions exceeding EUR 3000.
citing_justification: Court restricts scope of permissible online publication of personal data, requiring proportionality assessment that favors privacy over transparency.

citing_core_holding: The authority maintaining the commercial register is both a recipient and controller of personal data it publishes, even for non-required data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition ensures commercial register authority bears GDPR obligations for all published data.

citing_core_holding: A Member State cannot refuse erasure requests for non-required personal data solely because redacted document copies were not provided by the applicant.
citing_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

citing_core_holding: A Member State cannot refuse erasure requests for non-required personal data solely because redacted document copies were not provided by the applicant.
citing_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

citing_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

citing_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

citing_core_holding: A Member State cannot refuse erasure requests for non-required personal data solely because redacted document copies were not provided by the applicant.
citing_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.

citing_core_holding: A handwritten signature of a natural person constitutes personal data under the GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data to include handwritten signatures expands scope of GDPR protection.

citing_core_holding: Loss of control over personal data for a limited period may constitute compensable non-material damage if the data subject proves actual damage occurred.
citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_core_holding: Loss of control over personal data for a limited period may constitute compensable non-material damage if the data subject proves actual damage occurred.
citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

citing_core_holding: A non-binding supervisory authority opinion cannot exempt the controller from liability under Article 82(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Controllers cannot escape liability by relying on DPA opinions, maintaining strong accountability standards.

citing_core_holding: A non-binding supervisory authority opinion cannot exempt the controller from liability under Article 82(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Controllers cannot escape liability by relying on DPA opinions, maintaining strong accountability standards.

citing_core_holding: A non-binding supervisory authority opinion cannot exempt the controller from liability under Article 82(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Controllers cannot escape liability by relying on DPA opinions, maintaining strong accountability standards.

citing_core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

citing_core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

citing_core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

citing_core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

citing_core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

citing_core_holding: When information under Article 15(1)(h) contains third-party data or trade secrets, the controller must provide it to the supervisory authority or court to balance competing interests.
citing_justification: Balances data subject access rights against trade secrets and third-party rights, requiring case-by-case assessment rather than blanket exclusions; invalidates Austrian provision creating automatic exception.

citing_core_holding: When information under Article 15(1)(h) contains third-party data or trade secrets, the controller must provide it to the supervisory authority or court to balance competing interests.
citing_justification: Balances data subject access rights against trade secrets and third-party rights, requiring case-by-case assessment rather than blanket exclusions; invalidates Austrian provision creating automatic exception.

citing_core_holding: When information under Article 15(1)(h) contains third-party data or trade secrets, the controller must provide it to the supervisory authority or court to balance competing interests.
citing_justification: Balances data subject access rights against trade secrets and third-party rights, requiring case-by-case assessment rather than blanket exclusions; invalidates Austrian provision creating automatic exception.

citing_core_holding: National legislation providing for systematic collection of biometric and genetic data of all persons accused of intentional public prosecution offences is precluded without verification that collection is strictly necessary.
citing_justification: The holding prohibits systematic blanket collection of sensitive biometric and genetic data, requiring individualized necessity assessment and limiting law enforcement discretion.

citing_core_holding: An official journal may be classified as a controller of personal data in published documents even without legal personality, where national law determines the purposes and means of processing.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include official journals ensures data subjects can exercise their rights against the publishing entity.

citing_core_holding: An official journal may be classified as a controller of personal data in published documents even without legal personality, where national law determines the purposes and means of processing.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include official journals ensures data subjects can exercise their rights against the publishing entity.

citing_core_holding: The official journal is solely responsible for compliance with Article 5(1) principles for its processing operations unless national law establishes joint responsibility with other entities in the processing chain.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies allocation of responsibility without expanding or restricting either controller obligations or data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: A national authority keeping a public register must rectify personal data relating to gender identity where those data are inaccurate under the accuracy principle.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of rectification right prevents Member States from limiting gender identity rectification through absence of national procedures.

citing_core_holding: Member States cannot require proof of gender reassignment surgery as condition for exercising the right to rectification of gender identity data in public registers.
citing_justification: Prohibits surgery requirement for gender identity rectification, protecting transgender persons from disproportionate evidentiary burdens.

citing_core_holding: A national competition authority may find that a dominant undertaking's data processing terms are inconsistent with the GDPR when necessary to establish abuse of dominance, subject to sincere cooperation with data protection supervisory authorities.
citing_justification: The holding addresses institutional competence allocation between competition and data protection authorities, not substantive rights of data subjects or controllers.

citing_core_holding: Processing of off-platform data is necessary for contract performance only if objectively indispensable for a purpose integral to the contractual obligation, such that the contract's main subject matter cannot be achieved without it.
citing_justification: Strict interpretation of contract necessity prevents social networks from bundling unnecessary data processing into service contracts and claiming contractual basis.

citing_core_holding: Processing of off-platform data is necessary for contract performance only if objectively indispensable for a purpose integral to the contractual obligation, such that the contract's main subject matter cannot be achieved without it.
citing_justification: Strict interpretation of contract necessity prevents social networks from bundling unnecessary data processing into service contracts and claiming contractual basis.

citing_core_holding: Processing of off-platform data is necessary for contract performance only if objectively indispensable for a purpose integral to the contractual obligation, such that the contract's main subject matter cannot be achieved without it.
citing_justification: Strict interpretation of contract necessity prevents social networks from bundling unnecessary data processing into service contracts and claiming contractual basis.

citing_core_holding: Processing for legitimate interests requires informing users of the specific interest pursued, strict necessity, and a balancing test where users' interests and fundamental rights do not override the controller's legitimate interest.
citing_justification: Users' fundamental rights and reasonable expectations override controller's advertising interests; extensive tracking creates a feeling of continuous surveillance that overrides commercial interests.

citing_core_holding: Processing for legitimate interests requires informing users of the specific interest pursued, strict necessity, and a balancing test where users' interests and fundamental rights do not override the controller's legitimate interest.
citing_justification: Users' fundamental rights and reasonable expectations override controller's advertising interests; extensive tracking creates a feeling of continuous surveillance that overrides commercial interests.

citing_core_holding: A supervisory authority decision on a complaint is subject to full judicial review, not merely procedural review of whether the complaint was handled.
citing_justification: Establishes full judicial review of DPA decisions, strengthening data subject remedies against inadequate supervisory authority responses.

citing_core_holding: A supervisory authority decision on a complaint is subject to full judicial review, not merely procedural review of whether the complaint was handled.
citing_justification: Establishes full judicial review of DPA decisions, strengthening data subject remedies against inadequate supervisory authority responses.

citing_core_holding: Credit agencies cannot retain insolvency discharge data beyond the public register retention period as this fails the legitimate interest balancing test.
citing_justification: Limits credit agency data retention to public register period, restricting controller processing and prioritizing data subject rehabilitation interests.

citing_core_holding: Credit agencies cannot retain insolvency discharge data beyond the public register retention period as this fails the legitimate interest balancing test.
citing_justification: Limits credit agency data retention to public register period, restricting controller processing and prioritizing data subject rehabilitation interests.

citing_core_holding: Article 6(3) and (4) GDPR applies to the production in civil court proceedings of documents containing personal data originally collected for other purposes such as tax inspection.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies the scope of GDPR application to civil proceedings without expanding or restricting rights of either party.

citing_core_holding: Article 6(3) and (4) GDPR applies to the production in civil court proceedings of documents containing personal data originally collected for other purposes such as tax inspection.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies the scope of GDPR application to civil proceedings without expanding or restricting rights of either party.

citing_core_holding: When ordering document production containing personal data, national courts must balance data subject interests against other interests, applying proportionality and data minimisation principles.
citing_justification: Requires courts to actively consider data subject interests and apply data minimisation, including pseudonymisation and access restrictions, when ordering document production.

citing_core_holding: The mere infringement of GDPR provisions is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation; actual damage must be proven.
citing_justification: Requires proof of actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, limiting compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: National rules cannot make compensation for non-material damage conditional on the damage reaching a certain threshold of seriousness.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of damage concept prevents Member States from imposing seriousness thresholds that would limit compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: National rules cannot make compensation for non-material damage conditional on the damage reaching a certain threshold of seriousness.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of damage concept prevents Member States from imposing seriousness thresholds that would limit compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: Processing of personal data in the context of organizing elections in a Member State falls within the scope of the GDPR and is not excluded by Article 2(2)(a).
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope includes election-related data processing, rejecting narrow national security exception.

citing_core_holding: The controller must provide a data subject with a first free copy of personal data undergoing processing regardless of the reasons stated for the access request.
citing_justification: Strengthens right of access by confirming no justification is required for requesting a first free copy of personal data.

citing_core_holding: The controller must provide a data subject with a first free copy of personal data undergoing processing regardless of the reasons stated for the access request.
citing_justification: Strengthens right of access by confirming no justification is required for requesting a first free copy of personal data.

citing_core_holding: The controller must provide a data subject with a first free copy of personal data undergoing processing regardless of the reasons stated for the access request.
citing_justification: Strengthens right of access by confirming no justification is required for requesting a first free copy of personal data.

citing_core_holding: National legislation cannot require data subjects to bear the costs of a first copy of personal data in order to protect the economic interests of controllers.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion to restrict right of access and rejects economic interests of controllers as valid justification.

citing_core_holding: The right to a copy of personal data in medical records includes full copies of documents when necessary to ensure data are faithful, intelligible, and verifiable.
citing_justification: Expands scope of copy right to include full document copies when necessary for intelligibility, especially for sensitive health data.

citing_core_holding: Disclosure of banking data concerning judges and family members for integrity verification falls within the material scope of the GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection applies to judges' and family members' banking data.

citing_core_holding: Disclosure of banking data concerning judges and family members for integrity verification falls within the material scope of the GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection applies to judges' and family members' banking data.

citing_core_holding: Disclosure of banking data concerning judges and family members for integrity verification falls within the material scope of the GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection applies to judges' and family members' banking data.

citing_core_holding: Disclosure of banking data concerning judges and family members for integrity verification falls within the material scope of the GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope ensures data protection applies to judges' and family members' banking data.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.
citing_justification: Neither expands nor restricts data subject rights; clarifies that the authorizing court lacks sufficient control over processing to be a controller.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.
citing_justification: Neither expands nor restricts data subject rights; clarifies that the authorizing court lacks sufficient control over processing to be a controller.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.
citing_justification: Neither expands nor restricts data subject rights; clarifies that the authorizing court lacks sufficient control over processing to be a controller.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing disclosure of personal data to another judicial body is not a controller when it only verifies legal conditions without determining processing purposes.
citing_justification: Neither expands nor restricts data subject rights; clarifies that the authorizing court lacks sufficient control over processing to be a controller.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not a supervisory authority unless entrusted by the Member State with monitoring GDPR application.
citing_justification: Clarifies institutional roles without expanding or restricting data subject rights directly.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: A court authorizing data disclosure is not required to ensure data security compliance of its own motion when no Article 79 action is pending before it.
citing_justification: Limits judicial scrutiny of data security to cases where data subjects actively bring claims; authorizing courts need not investigate past breaches of their own motion.

citing_core_holding: Article 80(2) GDPR permits national legislation allowing consumer protection associations to bring representative actions without mandate and independently of specific data subject rights infringements.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of Article 80(2) allowing representative actions without mandate strengthens data subject rights through collective enforcement mechanisms.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary committee of inquiry activities are not excluded from GDPR scope merely because they are carried out by parliament exercising its power of scrutiny over the executive.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope extends protection to data subjects even when data is processed by parliamentary bodies.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary committee of inquiry activities are not excluded from GDPR scope merely because they are carried out by parliament exercising its power of scrutiny over the executive.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope extends protection to data subjects even when data is processed by parliamentary bodies.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary committee of inquiry activities are not excluded from GDPR scope merely because they are carried out by parliament exercising its power of scrutiny over the executive.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope extends protection to data subjects even when data is processed by parliamentary bodies.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary committee of inquiry activities are not excluded from GDPR scope merely because they are carried out by parliament exercising its power of scrutiny over the executive.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope extends protection to data subjects even when data is processed by parliamentary bodies.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary inquiry into political influence over a police state-protection authority is not a national security activity excluded from GDPR scope under Article 2(2)(a).
citing_justification: Narrow interpretation of national security exception ensures data subjects retain GDPR protection even when processing relates to entities with security functions.

citing_core_holding: Parliamentary inquiry into political influence over a police state-protection authority is not a national security activity excluded from GDPR scope under Article 2(2)(a).
citing_justification: Narrow interpretation of national security exception ensures data subjects retain GDPR protection even when processing relates to entities with security functions.

citing_core_holding: Where a Member State establishes only one supervisory authority, Articles 77(1) and 55(1) GDPR directly confer competence on that authority to hear complaints about parliamentary committee data processing.
citing_justification: Direct effect of complaint provisions ensures data subjects can enforce their rights through DPA regardless of Member State constitutional arrangements.

citing_core_holding: National legislation cannot constitute a more specific rule under Article 88(1) GDPR where it does not satisfy the conditions laid down in Article 88(2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring compliance with Article 88(2) safeguards for employees as data subjects.

citing_core_holding: National legislation cannot constitute a more specific rule under Article 88(1) GDPR where it does not satisfy the conditions laid down in Article 88(2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring compliance with Article 88(2) safeguards for employees as data subjects.

citing_core_holding: National legislation cannot constitute a more specific rule under Article 88(1) GDPR where it does not satisfy the conditions laid down in Article 88(2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring compliance with Article 88(2) safeguards for employees as data subjects.

citing_core_holding: Non-compliant national provisions on employee data processing must be disregarded unless they constitute a valid legal basis under Article 6(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Requires disapplication of non-compliant rules but preserves national provisions if they qualify as valid Article 6(3) legal bases.

citing_core_holding: Non-compliant national provisions on employee data processing must be disregarded unless they constitute a valid legal basis under Article 6(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Requires disapplication of non-compliant rules but preserves national provisions if they qualify as valid Article 6(3) legal bases.

citing_core_holding: Non-compliant national provisions on employee data processing must be disregarded unless they constitute a valid legal basis under Article 6(3) GDPR.
citing_justification: Requires disapplication of non-compliant rules but preserves national provisions if they qualify as valid Article 6(3) legal bases.

citing_core_holding: A data breach by third parties is not sufficient in itself to establish that the controller's technical and organisational measures were inappropriate under Articles 24 and 32 GDPR.
citing_justification: Controllers are not presumed to have failed merely because a breach occurred; they can rebut allegations with evidence of appropriate measures.

citing_core_holding: A data breach by third parties is not sufficient in itself to establish that the controller's technical and organisational measures were inappropriate under Articles 24 and 32 GDPR.
citing_justification: Controllers are not presumed to have failed merely because a breach occurred; they can rebut allegations with evidence of appropriate measures.

citing_core_holding: In compensation actions under Article 82 GDPR, the controller bears the burden of proving that its security measures were appropriate.
citing_justification: Placing the burden of proof on controllers strengthens data subject rights and ensures effectiveness of the compensation mechanism.

citing_core_holding: An expert report cannot be a systematically necessary and sufficient means of proof for assessing the appropriateness of security measures.
citing_justification: This holding addresses procedural rules on evidence rather than substantively favoring either party.

citing_core_holding: An expert report cannot be a systematically necessary and sufficient means of proof for assessing the appropriateness of security measures.
citing_justification: This holding addresses procedural rules on evidence rather than substantively favoring either party.

citing_core_holding: An expert report cannot be a systematically necessary and sufficient means of proof for assessing the appropriateness of security measures.
citing_justification: This holding addresses procedural rules on evidence rather than substantively favoring either party.

citing_core_holding: Fear of possible future misuse of personal data following a breach can in itself constitute compensable non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include fear of future misuse lowers the threshold for data subjects to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: The term undertaking in Article 83(4)-(6) GDPR corresponds to the competition law concept, so fines must be calculated based on group-wide turnover.
citing_justification: Allowing fines to be calculated on group-wide turnover significantly increases maximum fine amounts and deterrent effect against controllers.

citing_core_holding: Processing customer title data to personalize commercial communication is not necessary for contract performance or legitimate interests under the GDPR.
citing_justification: Court narrowly interprets contract and legitimate interest bases, finding title data processing not necessary; highlights discrimination risk for gender identity.

citing_core_holding: Processing customer title data to personalize commercial communication is not necessary for contract performance or legitimate interests under the GDPR.
citing_justification: Court narrowly interprets contract and legitimate interest bases, finding title data processing not necessary; highlights discrimination risk for gender identity.

citing_justification: Court narrowly interprets contract and legitimate interest bases, finding title data processing not necessary; highlights discrimination risk for gender identity.

citing_justification: Court narrowly interprets contract and legitimate interest bases, finding title data processing not necessary; highlights discrimination risk for gender identity.

citing_core_holding: The concept of "request" in Article 57(4) GDPR covers complaints lodged under Article 57(1)(f) and Article 77(1) GDPR with supervisory authorities.
citing_justification: Expands DPA powers to refuse complaints but only as an exception requiring strict interpretation, balancing DPA efficiency with data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: The concept of "request" in Article 57(4) GDPR covers complaints lodged under Article 57(1)(f) and Article 77(1) GDPR with supervisory authorities.
citing_justification: Expands DPA powers to refuse complaints but only as an exception requiring strict interpretation, balancing DPA efficiency with data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: Requests cannot be classified as excessive solely based on their number; the supervisory authority must demonstrate abusive intention by the complainant.
citing_justification: Sets high threshold for DPAs to refuse complaints by requiring proof of abusive intent, not mere high volume of complaints.

citing_core_holding: When faced with excessive requests, supervisory authorities may choose between charging a fee or refusing to act, provided the choice is appropriate, necessary, and proportionate.
citing_justification: Gives DPAs discretion but constrains it with proportionality requirements to protect data subjects from arbitrary refusals.

citing_core_holding: Personal data relating to penalty points imposed on drivers for road traffic offences falls within Article 10 GDPR as data relating to criminal offences.
citing_justification: Expands scope of Article 10 GDPR to cover road traffic offences despite their administrative classification under national law, enhancing data subject protections.

citing_core_holding: Personal data relating to penalty points imposed on drivers for road traffic offences falls within Article 10 GDPR as data relating to criminal offences.
citing_justification: Expands scope of Article 10 GDPR to cover road traffic offences despite their administrative classification under national law, enhancing data subject protections.

citing_core_holding: Personal data relating to penalty points imposed on drivers for road traffic offences falls within Article 10 GDPR as data relating to criminal offences.
citing_justification: Expands scope of Article 10 GDPR to cover road traffic offences despite their administrative classification under national law, enhancing data subject protections.

citing_core_holding: GDPR precludes national legislation obliging public disclosure of penalty points data to anyone without requiring a specific interest.
citing_justification: Finds public disclosure of penalty points data unlawful as disproportionate, prioritizing data subject privacy over transparency and road safety justifications.

citing_core_holding: GDPR precludes national legislation obliging public disclosure of penalty points data to anyone without requiring a specific interest.
citing_justification: Finds public disclosure of penalty points data unlawful as disproportionate, prioritizing data subject privacy over transparency and road safety justifications.

citing_core_holding: The data minimisation principle precludes unlimited aggregation and processing of all personal data from a social network platform for targeted advertising purposes.
citing_justification: Restricts controller's ability to aggregate and process unlimited personal data for advertising, strengthening data subject protection against pervasive tracking.

citing_core_holding: The data minimisation principle precludes unlimited aggregation and processing of all personal data from a social network platform for targeted advertising purposes.
citing_justification: Restricts controller's ability to aggregate and process unlimited personal data for advertising, strengthening data subject protection against pervasive tracking.

citing_justification: Restricts controller's ability to aggregate and process unlimited personal data for advertising, strengthening data subject protection against pervasive tracking.

citing_core_holding: Making a public statement about sexual orientation does not authorize processing of other data relating to that person's sexual orientation for advertising.
citing_justification: Narrow interpretation of Article 9(2)(e) exception prevents controller from using public disclosure of sensitive data to justify processing other related sensitive data.

citing_core_holding: Making a public statement about sexual orientation does not authorize processing of other data relating to that person's sexual orientation for advertising.
citing_justification: Narrow interpretation of Article 9(2)(e) exception prevents controller from using public disclosure of sensitive data to justify processing other related sensitive data.

citing_core_holding: National legislation may require just cause for dismissing a DPO beyond GDPR requirements, provided such legislation does not undermine GDPR objectives.
citing_justification: The Court permits Member States discretion to provide stronger DPO protections while allowing dismissal for conflict of interests, balancing both DPO protection and controller flexibility.

citing_core_holding: Article 82(1) GDPR precludes a de minimis threshold for non-material damage but data subjects must prove actual damage beyond mere infringement.
citing_justification: Rejects de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but requires proof of actual damage beyond mere infringement (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: Article 82(1) GDPR precludes a de minimis threshold for non-material damage but data subjects must prove actual damage beyond mere infringement.
citing_justification: Rejects de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but requires proof of actual damage beyond mere infringement (pro-controller).

citing_core_holding: A supervisory authority may order the erasure of unlawfully processed personal data without a prior request from the data subject.
citing_justification: Expands DPA powers to enforce erasure proactively, strengthening data subject protection even when individuals are unaware of unlawful processing.

citing_core_holding: A supervisory authority may order the erasure of unlawfully processed personal data without a prior request from the data subject.
citing_justification: Expands DPA powers to enforce erasure proactively, strengthening data subject protection even when individuals are unaware of unlawful processing.

citing_core_holding: For thumbnail image de-referencing requests, the informative value of photographs must be assessed independently regardless of original publication context.
citing_justification: Requires autonomous assessment of thumbnail displays favoring de-referencing since photographs outside original context have limited informative value while causing significant privacy interference.

citing_core_holding: A former guardian who performed duties professionally is a controller under Article 4(7) GDPR and must comply with the regulation including the right of access.
citing_justification: The Court confirms that a former guardian is a controller, thereby ensuring the data subject can exercise access rights against them.

citing_core_holding: The right to obtain a copy of personal data under Article 15(3) GDPR requires a faithful and intelligible reproduction of all data, including document extracts or entire documents where necessary for effective exercise of rights.
citing_justification: Expands the right of access to include copies of documents and database extracts where necessary to exercise rights effectively.

citing_core_holding: The right to obtain a copy of personal data under Article 15(3) GDPR requires a faithful and intelligible reproduction of all data, including document extracts or entire documents where necessary for effective exercise of rights.
citing_justification: Expands the right of access to include copies of documents and database extracts where necessary to exercise rights effectively.

citing_core_holding: The right to obtain a copy of personal data under Article 15(3) GDPR requires a faithful and intelligible reproduction of all data, including document extracts or entire documents where necessary for effective exercise of rights.
citing_justification: Expands the right of access to include copies of documents and database extracts where necessary to exercise rights effectively.

citing_core_holding: Online marketplace operators must identify advertisements containing sensitive data, verify advertiser identity, and refuse publication absent explicit consent from the data subject.
citing_justification: Imposes significant new obligations on marketplace operators to proactively identify sensitive data, verify identity, and refuse publication, expanding controller accountability.

citing_core_holding: Online marketplace operators must identify advertisements containing sensitive data, verify advertiser identity, and refuse publication absent explicit consent from the data subject.
citing_justification: Imposes significant new obligations on marketplace operators to proactively identify sensitive data, verify identity, and refuse publication, expanding controller accountability.

citing_core_holding: Online marketplace operators must identify advertisements containing sensitive data, verify advertiser identity, and refuse publication absent explicit consent from the data subject.
citing_justification: Imposes significant new obligations on marketplace operators to proactively identify sensitive data, verify identity, and refuse publication, expanding controller accountability.

citing_core_holding: Online marketplace operators must implement security measures to prevent sensitive data advertisements from being copied and unlawfully published on other websites.
citing_justification: Requires marketplace operators to implement technical measures preventing copying and reproduction of sensitive data, enhancing protection against permanent harm.

citing_core_holding: Online marketplace operators must implement security measures to prevent sensitive data advertisements from being copied and unlawfully published on other websites.
citing_justification: Requires marketplace operators to implement technical measures preventing copying and reproduction of sensitive data, enhancing protection against permanent harm.

citing_core_holding: A GDPR infringement alone does not constitute damage; actual damage must be separately established to claim compensation under Article 82(1).
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: A GDPR infringement alone does not constitute damage; actual damage must be separately established to claim compensation under Article 82(1).
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: An apology may constitute sufficient compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) if it fully compensates the damage suffered.
citing_justification: Allows non-monetary compensation (apology) which could benefit controllers, but requires full compensation which protects data subjects.

citing_core_holding: An apology may constitute sufficient compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) if it fully compensates the damage suffered.
citing_justification: Allows non-monetary compensation (apology) which could benefit controllers, but requires full compensation which protects data subjects.

citing_core_holding: Controller attitude and motivation cannot be used to reduce compensation below the actual damage suffered by the data subject.
citing_justification: Prevents controllers from using good faith or public interest motivations to reduce compensation below actual damage suffered.

citing_core_holding: Controller attitude and motivation cannot be used to reduce compensation below the actual damage suffered by the data subject.
citing_justification: Prevents controllers from using good faith or public interest motivations to reduce compensation below actual damage suffered.

citing_core_holding: Controller attitude and motivation cannot be used to reduce compensation below the actual damage suffered by the data subject.
citing_justification: Prevents controllers from using good faith or public interest motivations to reduce compensation below actual damage suffered.

citing_core_holding: Article 15 GDPR applies to access requests submitted after 25 May 2018 even if the underlying processing occurred before that date.
citing_justification: Broad temporal application expands scope of access rights to cover pre-GDPR processing operations.

citing_core_holding: Data subjects have a right of access to log data concerning dates and purposes of consultation operations, but not to employee identities unless essential for exercising GDPR rights and balanced against employee rights.
citing_justification: Expands access to log data (dates, purposes) but limits access to employee identities by requiring balancing with employee rights.

citing_core_holding: Data subjects have a right of access to log data concerning dates and purposes of consultation operations, but not to employee identities unless essential for exercising GDPR rights and balanced against employee rights.
citing_justification: Expands access to log data (dates, purposes) but limits access to employee identities by requiring balancing with employee rights.

citing_core_holding: Data subjects have a right of access to log data concerning dates and purposes of consultation operations, but not to employee identities unless essential for exercising GDPR rights and balanced against employee rights.
citing_justification: Expands access to log data (dates, purposes) but limits access to employee identities by requiring balancing with employee rights.

citing_core_holding: A GDPR infringement alone does not confer a right to compensation; the data subject must prove actual damage, though no severity threshold applies.
citing_justification: Requires proof of damage (pro-controller) but rejects severity threshold (pro-data subject).

citing_core_holding: A GDPR infringement alone does not confer a right to compensation; the data subject must prove actual damage, though no severity threshold applies.
citing_justification: Requires proof of damage (pro-controller) but rejects severity threshold (pro-data subject).

citing_core_holding: Fear of personal data disclosure to third parties can constitute compensable non-material damage if the fear and its negative consequences are duly proven.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage allows compensation for fear even without proving actual disclosure.

citing_core_holding: Fear of personal data disclosure to third parties can constitute compensable non-material damage if the fear and its negative consequences are duly proven.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage allows compensation for fear even without proving actual disclosure.

citing_core_holding: Article 83 administrative fine criteria do not apply to compensation assessment, and Article 82 compensation has no dissuasive or punitive function.
citing_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive or dissuasive elements, reducing potential liability.

citing_core_holding: Article 83 administrative fine criteria do not apply to compensation assessment, and Article 82 compensation has no dissuasive or punitive function.
citing_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive or dissuasive elements, reducing potential liability.

citing_core_holding: A TC String encoding user consent preferences constitutes personal data when it can be associated by reasonable means with identifiers allowing user identification.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope captures TC Strings even when organization lacks direct access to combined identifiers.

citing_core_holding: A TC String encoding user consent preferences constitutes personal data when it can be associated by reasonable means with identifiers allowing user identification.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope captures TC Strings even when organization lacks direct access to combined identifiers.

citing_core_holding: A TC String encoding user consent preferences constitutes personal data when it can be associated by reasonable means with identifiers allowing user identification.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope captures TC Strings even when organization lacks direct access to combined identifiers.

citing_core_holding: A TC String encoding user consent preferences constitutes personal data when it can be associated by reasonable means with identifiers allowing user identification.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope captures TC Strings even when organization lacks direct access to combined identifiers.

citing_core_holding: A sectoral organization establishing binding technical rules for consent management is a joint controller even without direct data access, but controllership does not automatically extend to subsequent third-party processing.
citing_justification: Broad joint controller interpretation extends accountability but limits do not automatically extend to subsequent processing, balancing controller burden.

citing_core_holding: Valid consent requires active behaviour by the data subject with prior clear information, and cannot be established through pre-ticked boxes, misleading contract terms, or requirements to formally refuse consent.
citing_justification: The Court imposes strict requirements on controllers for demonstrating valid consent, rejecting pre-ticked boxes and requiring active behaviour from data subjects.

citing_core_holding: Commercial interests can constitute legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR, but processing must be strictly necessary and fundamental rights must not override the legitimate interest.
citing_justification: The Court emphasizes strict necessity, data minimization, and reasonable expectations of data subjects, suggesting that selling member data without consent is unlikely to satisfy Article 6(1)(f) requirements.

citing_core_holding: Commercial interests can constitute legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR, but processing must be strictly necessary and fundamental rights must not override the legitimate interest.
citing_justification: The Court emphasizes strict necessity, data minimization, and reasonable expectations of data subjects, suggesting that selling member data without consent is unlikely to satisfy Article 6(1)(f) requirements.

citing_core_holding: Commercial interests can constitute legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR, but processing must be strictly necessary and fundamental rights must not override the legitimate interest.
citing_justification: The Court emphasizes strict necessity, data minimization, and reasonable expectations of data subjects, suggesting that selling member data without consent is unlikely to satisfy Article 6(1)(f) requirements.

citing_core_holding: Credit scoring by a credit information agency constitutes automated individual decision-making under Article 22(1) GDPR when a third party relies strongly on that score for contractual decisions.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of automated decision-making extends Article 22 protections to credit scoring, expanding data subject rights and controller obligations.

citing_core_holding: Credit scoring by a credit information agency constitutes automated individual decision-making under Article 22(1) GDPR when a third party relies strongly on that score for contractual decisions.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of automated decision-making extends Article 22 protections to credit scoring, expanding data subject rights and controller obligations.

citing_core_holding: National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
citing_justification: Allows entities without legal personality to be controllers (pro-controller flexibility) but requires them to fulfill all controller obligations toward data subjects (pro-data subject protection).

citing_core_holding: National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
citing_justification: Allows entities without legal personality to be controllers (pro-controller flexibility) but requires them to fulfill all controller obligations toward data subjects (pro-data subject protection).

citing_core_holding: National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
citing_justification: Allows entities without legal personality to be controllers (pro-controller flexibility) but requires them to fulfill all controller obligations toward data subjects (pro-data subject protection).

citing_core_holding: National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
citing_justification: Allows entities without legal personality to be controllers (pro-controller flexibility) but requires them to fulfill all controller obligations toward data subjects (pro-data subject protection).

citing_core_holding: A non-lead supervisory authority may initiate legal proceedings regarding cross-border processing only in specific situations where GDPR confers decision-making competence on it.
citing_justification: Allows non-lead DPA to bring proceedings in limited circumstances but confirms one-stop-shop constraints on enforcement powers.

citing_core_holding: National rules adopted under Article 88(1) GDPR for employment data processing must also comply with the requirements of Articles 5, 6(1), and 9(1) and (2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring full compliance with core GDPR data protection principles even when adopting specific employment rules.

citing_core_holding: National rules adopted under Article 88(1) GDPR for employment data processing must also comply with the requirements of Articles 5, 6(1), and 9(1) and (2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring full compliance with core GDPR data protection principles even when adopting specific employment rules.

citing_core_holding: National rules adopted under Article 88(1) GDPR for employment data processing must also comply with the requirements of Articles 5, 6(1), and 9(1) and (2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring full compliance with core GDPR data protection principles even when adopting specific employment rules.

citing_core_holding: National rules adopted under Article 88(1) GDPR for employment data processing must also comply with the requirements of Articles 5, 6(1), and 9(1) and (2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring full compliance with core GDPR data protection principles even when adopting specific employment rules.

citing_core_holding: National courts must conduct full judicial review of collective agreements to verify necessity of data processing, notwithstanding the parties' margin of discretion.
citing_justification: Ensures employees can challenge collective agreements that inadequately protect their data rights through full judicial review.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR does not provide a judicial remedy for data subjects to obtain preventive injunctions against future unlawful processing, but Member States may establish such remedies under national law.
citing_justification: While not creating a new EU-level remedy, the ruling preserves Member State discretion to provide preventive remedies, neither expanding nor restricting existing rights.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR does not provide a judicial remedy for data subjects to obtain preventive injunctions against future unlawful processing, but Member States may establish such remedies under national law.
citing_justification: While not creating a new EU-level remedy, the ruling preserves Member State discretion to provide preventive remedies, neither expanding nor restricting existing rights.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR does not provide a judicial remedy for data subjects to obtain preventive injunctions against future unlawful processing, but Member States may establish such remedies under national law.
citing_justification: While not creating a new EU-level remedy, the ruling preserves Member State discretion to provide preventive remedies, neither expanding nor restricting existing rights.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

citing_core_holding: The degree of fault on the part of the controller cannot be taken into account when assessing the amount of compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Excluding degree of fault from damage assessment limits the amount controllers may have to pay, preventing punitive or enhanced damages based on culpability.

citing_core_holding: The degree of fault on the part of the controller cannot be taken into account when assessing the amount of compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Excluding degree of fault from damage assessment limits the amount controllers may have to pay, preventing punitive or enhanced damages based on culpability.

citing_core_holding: The degree of fault on the part of the controller cannot be taken into account when assessing the amount of compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Excluding degree of fault from damage assessment limits the amount controllers may have to pay, preventing punitive or enhanced damages based on culpability.

citing_core_holding: Obtaining a prohibitory injunction under national law cannot reduce or replace the financial compensation for non-material damage payable under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Preventing reduction or substitution of financial compensation ensures data subjects receive full monetary redress regardless of other remedies obtained.

citing_core_holding: Obtaining a prohibitory injunction under national law cannot reduce or replace the financial compensation for non-material damage payable under Article 82(1) GDPR.
citing_justification: Preventing reduction or substitution of financial compensation ensures data subjects receive full monetary redress regardless of other remedies obtained.

citing_core_holding: Verification of COVID-19 certificates using a mobile application constitutes processing of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of processing captures mobile app verification activities that might otherwise escape GDPR regulation.

citing_core_holding: Verification of COVID-19 certificates using a mobile application constitutes processing of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) GDPR.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of processing captures mobile app verification activities that might otherwise escape GDPR regulation.

citing_core_holding: The Article 9(2)(h) exception applies when a medical service processes health data of its own employee to assess working capacity, provided it acts as medical service not employer.
citing_justification: Allows medical service to process health data of its own employees, recognizing dual function and rejecting requirement for neutral third party.

citing_core_holding: The Article 9(2)(h) exception applies when a medical service processes health data of its own employee to assess working capacity, provided it acts as medical service not employer.
citing_justification: Allows medical service to process health data of its own employees, recognizing dual function and rejecting requirement for neutral third party.

citing_core_holding: The Article 9(2)(h) exception applies when a medical service processes health data of its own employee to assess working capacity, provided it acts as medical service not employer.
citing_justification: Allows medical service to process health data of its own employees, recognizing dual function and rejecting requirement for neutral third party.

citing_core_holding: Article 9(3) does not require controllers to prevent all colleagues from accessing employee health data, though Member State law or security principles may impose such obligations.
citing_justification: Does not require absolute colleague exclusion under Article 9(3), but recognizes Member States may impose such requirements and security principles apply.

citing_core_holding: Processing health data under Article 9(2)(h) must also satisfy at least one lawfulness condition under Article 6(1) in addition to Article 9 requirements.
citing_justification: Requires cumulative compliance with both Article 9 and Article 6(1), increasing controller obligations for health data processing.

citing_core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) fulfils a compensatory function only, not a dissuasive or punitive function.
citing_justification: Rejects punitive damages function, limiting compensation to actual damage suffered and excluding consideration of infringement gravity.

citing_core_holding: Controller liability under Article 82 requires fault, which is presumed but rebuttable; fault severity does not affect damages amount.
citing_justification: Presumed fault benefits data subjects by reversing burden of proof, but excluding fault severity from damages calculation benefits controllers.

citing_core_holding: Controller liability under Article 82 requires fault, which is presumed but rebuttable; fault severity does not affect damages amount.
citing_justification: Presumed fault benefits data subjects by reversing burden of proof, but excluding fault severity from damages calculation benefits controllers.

citing_core_holding: An entity commissioning a mobile app may be a controller if it participated in determining processing purposes and means, even without performing processing operations itself.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of controller captures entities that commission apps but do not themselves process data, expanding accountability.

citing_core_holding: Using personal data for IT testing constitutes processing unless the data are anonymous, anonymized, or fictitious relating to non-existent persons.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of processing covers IT testing purposes, expanding GDPR applicability to development activities.

citing_core_holding: Administrative fines require intentional or negligent infringement; controllers may be fined for processor operations unless processor acted outside the agreed framework.
citing_justification: Requires fault for fines (pro-controller) but allows controller liability for processor actions within agreed scope (pro-data subject).

citing_core_holding: Administrative fines require intentional or negligent infringement; controllers may be fined for processor operations unless processor acted outside the agreed framework.
citing_justification: Requires fault for fines (pro-controller) but allows controller liability for processor actions within agreed scope (pro-data subject).

citing_core_holding: Employee error in providing documents containing personal data to an unauthorized third party is not sufficient in itself to conclude that the controller's technical and organizational measures were inappropriate.
citing_justification: Holding prevents automatic finding of inadequate security measures based solely on occurrence of a breach, requiring concrete assessment that benefits controllers.

citing_core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82 fulfills a compensatory function requiring full compensation for damage suffered, not a punitive function.
citing_justification: Clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or limiting rights in a way that favors either party.

citing_core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82 fulfills a compensatory function requiring full compensation for damage suffered, not a punitive function.
citing_justification: Clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or limiting rights in a way that favors either party.

citing_core_holding: Article 82 does not require that the severity of the controller's infringement be taken into consideration when determining compensation amounts.
citing_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage without allowing increases based on severity of infringement, benefiting controllers facing minor but technically serious violations.

citing_core_holding: A person seeking compensation must establish both an infringement of the GDPR and that the infringement caused material or non-material damage.
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.

citing_core_holding: A person seeking compensation must establish both an infringement of the GDPR and that the infringement caused material or non-material damage.
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.

citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.
