citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.

citing_core_holding: When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.
citing_justification: Excludes compensation for hypothetical fear when unauthorized party did not actually access the data, limiting recoverable non-material damage.

citing_core_holding: When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.
citing_justification: Excludes compensation for hypothetical fear when unauthorized party did not actually access the data, limiting recoverable non-material damage.

citing_core_holding: When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.
citing_justification: Excludes compensation for hypothetical fear when unauthorized party did not actually access the data, limiting recoverable non-material damage.

citing_core_holding: Data identifying a natural person representing a legal person (name, surname, signature, contact details) constitutes personal data, and its disclosure is processing regardless of purpose.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope includes representatives of legal persons, expanding GDPR protection.

citing_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope includes representatives of legal persons, expanding GDPR protection.

citing_core_holding: National case-law requiring prior consultation of data subjects before disclosure of official documents is permissible provided it does not impose disproportionate restrictions on public access.
citing_justification: Permits national data subject protections but limits them through proportionality to protect public access rights.

citing_core_holding: National case-law requiring prior consultation of data subjects before disclosure of official documents is permissible provided it does not impose disproportionate restrictions on public access.
citing_justification: Permits national data subject protections but limits them through proportionality to protect public access rights.

citing_justification: Permits national data subject protections but limits them through proportionality to protect public access rights.

citing_core_holding: Oral disclosure of information on criminal proceedings concerning a natural person constitutes processing of personal data falling within the GDPR's material scope when the data form part of a filing system.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of processing to include oral disclosure expands GDPR scope and prevents circumvention of data protection rules.

citing_core_holding: Oral disclosure of information on criminal proceedings concerning a natural person constitutes processing of personal data falling within the GDPR's material scope when the data form part of a filing system.
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of processing to include oral disclosure expands GDPR scope and prevents circumvention of data protection rules.

citing_core_holding: Criminal conviction data in court filing systems cannot be disclosed orally to any person for public access purposes without the requester establishing a specific interest in obtaining the data.
citing_justification: Court requires specific interest to be established before disclosure, prioritizing data subject privacy over unrestricted public access to criminal records.

citing_core_holding: Criminal conviction data in court filing systems cannot be disclosed orally to any person for public access purposes without the requester establishing a specific interest in obtaining the data.
citing_justification: Court requires specific interest to be established before disclosure, prioritizing data subject privacy over unrestricted public access to criminal records.

citing_core_holding: An infringement of GDPR provisions conferring rights on data subjects is not sufficient in itself to constitute non-material damage requiring compensation.
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: An infringement of GDPR provisions conferring rights on data subjects is not sufficient in itself to constitute non-material damage requiring compensation.
citing_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

citing_core_holding: A controller cannot be exempted from liability merely by claiming that damage was caused by an employee's failure to follow instructions.
citing_justification: Controllers remain liable for employee failures and cannot easily escape responsibility, strengthening data subject compensation rights.

citing_core_holding: A controller cannot be exempted from liability merely by claiming that damage was caused by an employee's failure to follow instructions.
citing_justification: Controllers remain liable for employee failures and cannot easily escape responsibility, strengthening data subject compensation rights.

citing_justification: Controllers remain liable for employee failures and cannot easily escape responsibility, strengthening data subject compensation rights.

citing_core_holding: Administrative fine criteria under Article 83 do not apply to compensation assessment, and multiple infringements do not increase damages beyond actual harm suffered.
citing_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive elements, preventing inflation of damages through multiple infringement counts.

citing_core_holding: Administrative fine criteria under Article 83 do not apply to compensation assessment, and multiple infringements do not increase damages beyond actual harm suffered.
citing_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive elements, preventing inflation of damages through multiple infringement counts.

citing_core_holding: Consumer protection associations may bring representative actions under Article 80(2) GDPR for violations of controller information obligations under Articles 12(1) and 13(1)(c) and (e).
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of standing requirements allows consumer associations to bring actions for transparency violations, enhancing enforcement of data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: Consumer protection associations may bring representative actions under Article 80(2) GDPR for violations of controller information obligations under Articles 12(1) and 13(1)(c) and (e).
citing_justification: Broad interpretation of standing requirements allows consumer associations to bring actions for transparency violations, enhancing enforcement of data subject rights.

citing_core_holding: When a personal data breach is established, the supervisory authority is not required to exercise corrective powers where such action is not appropriate, necessary, or proportionate.
citing_justification: The ruling confirms that supervisory authorities have discretion not to impose fines or corrective measures even when a breach is established, reducing enforcement pressure on controllers.

citing_core_holding: When a personal data breach is established, the supervisory authority is not required to exercise corrective powers where such action is not appropriate, necessary, or proportionate.
citing_justification: The ruling confirms that supervisory authorities have discretion not to impose fines or corrective measures even when a breach is established, reducing enforcement pressure on controllers.

citing_core_holding: When a personal data breach is established, the supervisory authority is not required to exercise corrective powers where such action is not appropriate, necessary, or proportionate.
citing_justification: The ruling confirms that supervisory authorities have discretion not to impose fines or corrective measures even when a breach is established, reducing enforcement pressure on controllers.

citing_core_holding: The purpose limitation principle does not preclude copying personal data to a test database for testing and error correction where such processing is compatible with the initial collection purposes.
citing_justification: The Court permits controllers flexibility to copy data to test databases for legitimate operational purposes without requiring separate consent or legal basis.

citing_core_holding: The purpose limitation principle does not preclude copying personal data to a test database for testing and error correction where such processing is compatible with the initial collection purposes.
citing_justification: The Court permits controllers flexibility to copy data to test databases for legitimate operational purposes without requiring separate consent or legal basis.

citing_core_holding: The storage limitation principle precludes retaining personal data in a test database longer than necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors.
citing_justification: The Court strictly enforces storage limitation, rejecting the controller's oversight argument and requiring deletion once the test purpose is fulfilled.

citing_core_holding: The storage limitation principle precludes retaining personal data in a test database longer than necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors.
citing_justification: The Court strictly enforces storage limitation, rejecting the controller's oversight argument and requiring deletion once the test purpose is fulfilled.

citing_core_holding: National law cannot require that a GDPR infringement be attributed to an identified natural person before imposing an administrative fine on a legal person controller.
citing_justification: Holding ensures effective enforcement by allowing direct fines on legal person controllers without requiring attribution to a natural person.

citing_core_holding: An administrative fine under Article 83 GDPR may only be imposed where the controller intentionally or negligently committed the infringement.
citing_justification: Requires proof of intentional or negligent conduct before imposing administrative fines, rejecting strict liability.

citing_core_holding: The GDPR applies to PNR data processing by private operators and to API/maritime directive processing, but not to PNR Directive processing carried out by PIUs or competent authorities.
citing_justification: The holding clarifies the boundary between GDPR and Directive 2016/680 without expanding or restricting rights.
